awd_titl_txt: CAS: Understanding the Contributions from Both Thermal and Non-Thermal Factors in Plasmonic Catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Dr. Jie Liu of Duke University to develop a comprehensive fundamental understanding of plasmonic photocatalysis. Renewable energy such as sunlight for chemical manufacturing will impact the future of the chemical industry significantly. When nanoparticles interact with light an electronic phenomenon known as a surface plasmon is created. These surface plasmons can significantly affect the way the surfaces chemically react. Plasmonic catalysis, a recent direction in catalysis, captures light energy from the sun and uses it to accelerate important chemical reactions. However, the mechanism of plasmonic catalysis is complicated because light also heats the nanoparticle surface. Separating the thermal (simple heating) and surface plasmon contributions to the observed chemical reactions is important to fundamental understanding. Only with such understanding will researchers be able to design systems to use sunlight at maximum efficiency. Dr. Liu and his team are developing experimental methods to distinguish these thermal and electronic effects. The results from the proposed research is providing deeper understanding of the mechanism behind plasmonic catalysis. In addition, Dr. Liu is focusing on converting CO2 to value-added chemicals such as methane and methanol using plasmonic catalysis. This approach could serve to close the carbon cycle, ideally resulting net zero carbon emission from the use and reductive capture of such one carbon fuels. In this project, Dr. Liu is fostering the engagement of female researchers as well as researchers from underrepresented minority groups. Dr. Liu is actively participating in the North Carolina American Chemical Society (ACS) Project SEED Program by hosting high school students from underrepresented groups during summers and the school yearencouraging them to become future research scientists.

Dr. Jie Liu of Duke University is developing a comprehensive fundamental understanding of plasmonic photocatalysis through an integrated macroscopic kinetic study of the CO2 reduction reaction with targeted spectroscopic investigations of the reaction dynamics on the surface of nanostructured rhodium, guided and interpreted by theoretical analyses. Once understood, the potential for plasmonic rate enhancement and selectivity control in photocatalytic reactions may be ascertained for a large variety of plasmonic materials. In addition, understanding the contributions from photo-thermal as well as non-thermal effect (e.g. hot electrons mediated catalytic process) is not only clarifying the mechanism but also enabling researchers to consider designing processes for more efficient use of energy from sunlight. Dr. Liu participates in the North Carolina American Chemical Society (ACS) Project SEED Program by hosting high school students from underrepresented groups during summers and the school year. Students in the program work with graduate students and Dr. Liu to design and perform scientific experiments. This program is supporting high school students to explore their interest in STEM fields thereby encouraging them to become future researchers in these fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF report focused on investigating the light and heating effects generated on plasmonic nanoparticles with their metal oxide support under light illumination. The main aim is to develop methods for both quantitatively and qualitatively separating the two effects and studying their synergetic outcome to improve the production rate.

Intellectual Merit: At the time when the project started, the research field had a limited understanding of the precise roles and mechanisms of nanoparticles in plasmonic catalysis, especially in solid-gas reactions. Hot-carriers generated under light illumination on plasmonic nanoparticles decay within femtoseconds, making it challenging to isolate local quantum effects and more global thermal effects accurately. The challenge is to understand how light affects plasmonic catalyst particles in extremely short timeframes and small spaces, as the particles heat up quickly and make it hard to separate the effects of light from heat. The PI and collaborators developed three experimental methods to quantitively isolate the nonthermal and thermal effects in these plasmonic photocatalytic reactions. The first and simplest method is to use thermocouples to measure temperatures at different locations in the catalyst bed to confirm the existence of the thermal effects and estimate both thermal and nonthermal effects by defining an equivalent average temperature of the catalyst systems. Additionally, a Raman thermometry method was also developed under this NSF project. It confirmed the accuracy of the thermocouple method and validated the temperature measured by the thermocouple with uncertainty within 10%. To more accurately measure the nonthermal effects, the group established a second method to measure the differences between bare catalysts and catalysts covered by a layer of inert photothermal material under the same thermal conditions. Lastly, the group developed a mass-dependent method to mathematically extrapolate the nonthermal contribution in the plasmonic photocatalysis process, by gradually replacing the thickness of the catalyst and plotting the reaction rate as a function of catalyst thickness. Assuming light only penetrates a very thin layer of catalyst, the reaction rate extrapolated at zero thickness should be the accurate nonthermally accelerated reaction rate. These developed methods were tested in various reaction systems, proving their general applicability in measuring, and separating thermal and nonthermal effects. The PI also proposed a new index, overall light effectiveness (OLE), as a more suitable parameter for analyzing contributions from both thermal and nonthermal light effects and studying their synergy to achieve maximum efficiency. This study highlights the importance of understanding the combined effects of light and heat for future research.

Broader Impacts: Publications from this project not only contributed to the general understanding of the plasmonic catalysis mechanisms but also paved the way for the development of more efficient approaches to using broad-spectrum sunlight to produce important chemicals. Using renewable and abundant sunlight as the energy source for chemical reactions rather than electricity that largely originated from fossil fuels, can reduce the overall carbon footprints of many chemical processes. For example, the reaction between carbon dioxide and hydrogen studied in this project can be considered as an efficient way for hydrogen storage as well as carbon dioxide fixation, both are important for society in the fight against climate change. In addition, this project has trained several graduate researchers and provided them with multiple opportunities to publish their work in peer-reviewed journals and to presentations at top conferences. Graduate students have also actively participated in the Duke Materials Initiative and Duke Climate Change Initiative activities by presenting posters and facilitating cross-disciplinary research collaborations. Some of the PI’s work was summarized in the first published textbook on plasmonic catalysis, Plasmonic Catalysis: From Fundamentals to Applications in 2021. This comprehensive work highlights the field's fundamentals and applications, contributing significantly to the academic and research community.
